title: 112_hr2881
content: The "Foreign Service Line of Duty Death Gratuity Act of 2011" increases the death gratuity to $100,000 or one year's salary at the time of death, whichever is greater. It also amends the Foreign Service Act of 1980 to provide increased group life insurance benefits for those killed in the line of duty. The Foreign Service Line of Duty Death Gratuity Act of 2011 increases the death gratuity to $100,000 or one year's salary at the time of death, whichever is greater. Additionally, a Foreign Service or Government executive branch employee killed in the line of duty due to an act of violence in a designated combat operation or zone will be insured for $400,000 under chapter 87 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 4. REQUIREMENT TO PROVIDE COMPENSATION. The Secretary of State must provide a death gratuity payment to the surviving dependents of Foreign Service or Government executive branch employees serving abroad, as specified in the Foreign Service Act of 1980. The Secretary of State is required to provide a death gratuity payment to eligible individuals who were killed in the 1998 bombing of the US Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya. Payments must be made within 180 days of the enactment of the Act, with additional payments authorized as appropriations become available. The minimum payment amount is specified. The death gratuity payment for individuals killed in the 1998 bombing of the US Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya must be equal to or greater than $4,000,000 previously appropriated. The payment amount is calculated as ten times the specified salary under the Foreign Service Act of 1980. The salary used for determining payments is $94,000. Appropriations are authorized for the Secretary of State to make payments under this section.
